--- title: "Lecture 09: Transforming Variables" date: 'Last updated: 2023-03-14' --- ## ðŸ“‹ Lecture Outline - Qualitative variables - Dummy variables - Intercept offset - t-test - Centering - Scaling - Interactions - Polynomial transformations for non-linearity - Log transformations for non-linearity ## Qualitative Variables ::: {.cell} ::: ::::::::: {.r-stack} :::::::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Sex Insensitive Model
(Intercept) 23.495 0.809 29.04 0
education -0.839 0.067 -12.54 0
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=1 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Sex Insensitive Model
(Intercept) 23.495 0.809 29.036 0
education -0.839 0.067 -12.540 0
Sex Sensitive Model
(Intercept) -1.660 0.441 -3.761 0
education 0.674 0.028 23.732 0
sex(male) 16.556 0.266 62.311 0
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: ::::::::: ## Dummy Variables ::::::::: {.r-stack} :::::::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} __Dummy variables__ code each observation: $x_i=\left\{\begin{array}{c l} 1 & \text{if i in category} \\ 0 & \text{if i not in category} \end{array}\right.$ with zero being the __reference class__. For _m_ categories, requires _m-1_ dummy variables. ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Category D1 D2 … Dm-1

D1

1

0

0

0

D2

0

1

0

0

â‹®

â‹®

â‹®

â‹®

â‹®

Dm-1

0

0

0

1

Dm

0

0

0

0
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} __Dummy variables__ code each observation: $sex_i=\left\{\begin{array}{c l} 1 & \text{if i-th person is male} \\ 0 & \text{if i-th person is not male} \end{array}\right.$ Here the __reference class__ is _female_. The sex variable has two categories, hence one dummy variable. ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
sex male

male

1

female

0

â‹®

â‹®

male

1

female

0
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: ::::::::: ## Intercept Offset ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.blank-table} | | | |------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------| | Simple linear model | $y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_1 + \epsilon_i$ | | Add dummy $D$ with $\gamma$ offset | $y_i = (\beta_0 + \gamma\cdot D) + \beta_1x_1 + \epsilon_i$ | | _for a binary class:_ | | | Model for reference class | $y_i = (\beta_0 + \gamma\cdot 0) + \beta_1x_1 + \epsilon_i$ | | Model for other class | $y_i = (\beta_0 + \gamma\cdot 1) + \beta_1x_1 + \epsilon_i$ | ::: ## t-test :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Sex Sensitive Model
(Intercept) 8.555 0.191 44.79 0
sex(male) 11.165 0.270 41.33 0
``` ::: ::: $H_{0}$: no difference in mean model: $income \sim sex$ $\bar{y}_{F} = 8.555$ $\bar{y}_{M} = \bar{y}_{F} + 11.165 = 19.72$ ::::: :::::: ## Centering ::::::::: {.r-stack} :::::::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Uncentered Model
(Intercept) 25.80 5.917 4.36 0
Mom's IQ 0.61 0.059 10.42 0
``` ::: ::: Model child IQ as a function of mother's IQ. ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Uncentered Model
(Intercept) 25.80 5.917 4.36 0
Mom's IQ 0.61 0.059 10.42 0
``` ::: ::: Model child IQ as a function of mother's IQ. ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=1 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} Centering will make intercept more interpretable. To center, subtract the mean: $$\text{Mom's IQ} - \text{mean(Mom's IQ)}$$ That gets us this model... ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=2 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Uncentered Model
(Intercept) 25.80 5.917 4.36 0
Mom's IQ 0.61 0.059 10.42 0
Centered Model
(Intercept) 86.80 0.877 98.99 0
Mom's IQ 0.61 0.059 10.42 0
``` ::: ::: Now we interpret the intercept as expected IQ of a child for a mother with mean IQ. (Notice change in standard error!) ::::: :::::: :::::::: ::::::::: ::: aside No commitment here to IQ being meaningful. Just an example I'm using till I have time to find a better one. ::: ## Scaling ::::::::: {.r-stack} :::::::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell fig.asp='1'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Unscaled Model
(Intercept) 37.227 1.599 23.285 0.000
Horsepower -0.032 0.009 -3.519 0.001
Weight -3.878 0.633 -6.129 0.000
``` ::: ::: Model fuel efficiency as a function of weight and horse power. __Question__ Which covariate has a bigger effect? ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell fig.asp='1'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} __Problem__ Cannot directly compare coefficients on different scales. __Solution__ Convert variable values to their z-scores: $$z_i = \frac{x_i-\bar{x}}{\sigma_{x}}$$ All coefficients now give change in $y$ for 1$\sigma$ change in $x$. ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=1 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell fig.asp='1'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Unscaled Model
(Intercept) 37.227 1.599 23.285 0.000
Horsepower -0.032 0.009 -3.519 0.001
Weight -3.878 0.633 -6.129 0.000
Scaled Model
(Intercept) 20.091 0.458 43.822 0.000
Horsepower -2.178 0.619 -3.519 0.001
Weight -3.794 0.619 -6.129 0.000
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: ::::::::: ## Interactions ::::::::: {.r-stack} :::::::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Additive Model
(Intercept) 86.80 0.877 98.99 0
Mom's IQ 0.61 0.059 10.42 0
``` ::: ::: __Question__ What if the relationship between child's IQ and mother's IQ depends on the mother's educational attainment? ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=0 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} Simple formula becomes: $$y_i = (\beta_0 + \gamma D) + (\beta_1x_1 + \omega D x_1) + \epsilon_i$$ With - $\gamma$ giving the change in $\beta_0$ and - $\omega$ giving the change in $\beta_1$. That's a __change in intercept__ and a __change in slope__! ::::: :::::: :::::::: :::::::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=1 .mt-0 .w100} :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
term estimate std.error t.statistic p.value
Additive Model
(Intercept) 86.797 0.877 98.993 0.000
Mom's IQ 0.610 0.059 10.423 0.000
Interactive Model
(Intercept) 85.407 2.218 38.502 0.000
Mom's IQ 0.969 0.148 6.531 0.000
High School 2.841 2.427 1.171 0.242
Mom's IQ x HS -0.484 0.162 -2.985 0.003
``` ::: ::: ::::: :::::: :::::::: ::::::::: ## Polynomial transformations for non-linearity :::::: {.r-stack} ::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0} ::: {.cell} ::: __Simple Linear Model:__ $y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \epsilon_{i}$ $R^2 = 0.3088$ ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-2.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=0} ::: {.cell} ::: __Quadratic Model:__ $y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \beta_{2}X^{2} + \epsilon_{i}$ $R^2=0.7636$ ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-2.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ::: :::::: ## Log transformations ::: {.cell} ::: :::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} ::: {.cell fig.asp='0.9'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::: ::::: {.column} __Logging__ a skewed variable normalizes it. This is the inverse of __exponentiation__: $$Y = log(exp(Y))$$ May be applied to $X$ and $Y$. __Question__: but, whyyyyyy??? ::::: :::::: ## Log transformations for non-linearity :::::: {.r-stack} ::: {.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=0} ::: {.cell} ::: __Simple Linear Model:__ $y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \epsilon_{i}$ $R^2 = 0.8325$ ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-2.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index=0} ::: {.cell} ::: __Log Linear Model:__ $log(y_{i}) = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \epsilon_{i}$ $R^2 = 0.9407$ ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-transforms-slides_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-2.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ::: :::::: ## âš ï¸ [Careful!]{.kobe} Have to take care how we interpret log-models! $\beta_1$ means...
:::::: {.columns} ::::: {.column} __Linear Model__ $y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \epsilon_{i}$ _Increase in Y for one unit increase in X._
__Log-Linear Model__ $log(y_{i}) = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X + \epsilon_{i}$ _Percent increase in Y for one unit increase in X._ ::::: ::::: {.column} __Linear-Log Model__ $y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}log(X) + \epsilon_{i}$ _Increase in Y for percent increase in X._
__Log-Log Model__ $log(y_{i}) = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}log(X) + \epsilon_{i}$ _Percent increase in Y for percent increase in X._ ::::: ::::::
